title: Silent Siren: Responding to a Psoriasis Flare With a Wise Heart

content: Recently, I unconsciously scratched the nape of my neck and came away with flakes of skin and blood underneath my fingernails. For weeks I have been raising my left hand to scratch the same itch at the bottom of my hairline. A tiny tingle. An irritating prickling.

My psoriasis has been in blissful remission for so long that I didn’t recognize this slow, yet persistent flare knocking at the back door. It stopped me in my tracks. It frightened me. It opened the floodgates to a cascade of catastrophizing thoughts and memories of pain, itch, and sting, messy and time-consuming routines, greasy ointments, and smelly shampoos.

Add to that the double coup de grâce of shame and fear that can accompany chronic, unsightly disease, and my monkey mind was off to the races. I am disgusting. I am careless. What if my whole scalp breaks out? What if my hands and feet erupt and crack open? What if this flare is my fault?

content: This is what recurrence anxiety sounds like.

It’s an explosion of “what ifs” jamming the gears of my mind, causing a corresponding clench in my stomach, my weak spot, my sensitive solar plexus still working to power all the way on after many years of corporeal neglect and dissociation and relatively fewer years of painstaking self-care and dedicated recovery.

Hard-wired for fear and protection, my brain and belly work in concert to churn out worst-case scenarios when facing stressors or change. In the face of this known enemy, my internal fearmongering is calibrated to overdrive in the remembering, the dreading, and the girding against waves of grief and disappointment that crash through my internal mechanics, washing away my hard-won wellness – perhaps dashed to the rocks by my very own hand.
Flight-fight-freeze-fawn.

For me, the most meaningful way to escape this dizzying mind-body undertow is to pause, tune in to my body, and counteract catastrophizing with self-compassion. It is a new-to-me and still wobbly practice, and it begins with a tender internal inquiry.
What’s Going On?

content: There’s been a lot of tumult at work. We recently lost my father-in-law to lung cancer and became responsible for his elderly, immobile, and infirm wife who is vulnerable, now living alone, and thousands of miles away. My husband is in deep grief and has been away periodically to manage the aftermath. I’m concerned about financing his trips and unwinding the mess we’ve been left with yet didn’t create.

Last week, my mom had to have a second skull repair surgery after complications from unexpected brain surgery in February. I am facing the rocky emotional terrain of step four in my 12-step recovery program and discovering my true self while navigating the whitewater of early sobriety. I’ve been enduring chronic headaches and vertigo. I’ve been sad and overwhelmed. I’ve been grateful and joyful. I’ve been angry and disillusioned.
How Are You Responding?

I’ve been largely leaning on my new-normal routine – eating well (enough), sleeping well (enough), keeping up my meditation practice, attending regular step meetings, tending to my mental health, openly and directly communicating with my husband, and allowing all my feelings.

How Are You Responding?

I’ve been largely leaning on my new-normal routine – eating well (enough), sleeping well (enough), keeping up my meditation practice, attending regular step meetings, tending to my mental health, openly and directly communicating with my husband, and allowing all my feelings.

content: And, at the same time, I’ve been soothing myself with food-related micro-binges, too much screen time, not enough activity, and perhaps most ruinously, falling off my own boundary bandwagon with too many yeses and not enough nos. I’ve been taking too much responsibility for what doesn’t belong to me. Ugh, survival traits.
What Do You Need?

Despite leaning on my routine, I feel exhausted and depleted, and my psoriasis is flaring for the first time in 5 years. And if there’s inflammation on the outside, there’s likely inflammation on the inside.

My normal routine works well during normal times. This has not been a normal time. For several months, it has been an exceedingly worrying, stressful, painful, and hypervigilant time of caretaking, coping, healing, and processing. I need to rest and to resource. I need to slow down and simplify. I crave stillness and quiet.

sections.heading: How Can You Make it Happen?
content: I must take some specific action on my own behalf. Sometimes, when I feel overwhelmed with health or life issues, I try to focus on the next three things I can do to address my extra needs, while still maintaining my normal self-care routine. Then the next three and the next three ... rinse and repeat.

content: I need to prevent this flare from progressing any further. First, I will order some Neutrogena T/Gel shampoo and make an appointment with my dermatologist. I need to slow down and relieve some of the extra pressure I’ve been feeling.

So, second, I will clear my schedule of all nonessential doings to create some breathing room myself, with a focus on being realistic about what I can and can’t handle right now. I need to ask for help, so I will make an appointment with my therapist to get the extra emotional support I need. Phew, OK.

I know that stress is one of the most common psoriasis triggers, and I was still caught off guard. The bloody flakes are a harbinger. They tell me that I am too far away from myself. That I need to return. That I need to begin again, once again.
